metadata.case_name: Petitioner v. State of Madhya Pradesh

facts.text: Petitioner's husband, Shri Balirambhau Doye, proprietor of forests in eight Tehsils, granted petitioner rights to take and appropriate all kinds of wood (building wood, fuel wood, bamboos etc.) from said forests via unregistered document dated April 26, 1948, for period up to December 26, 1960, for consideration of Rs. 26,000.
Genuineness of document and good faith of parties not questioned.

Madhya Pradesh Abolition of Proprietary Rights (Estates, Mahals, Alienated Lands) Act, 1950 enacted; came into force January 26, 1951; under s.3, proprietary rights vested in State on March 31, 1951 for this area.
After vesting, petitioner stopped from cutting trees.

Petitioner applied to Deputy Commissioner, Bhandara under s.6 of the Act; on August 16, 1955, held s.6 not applicable as transfer pre-dated March 16, 1950, but allowed petitioner to work forests subject to lease conditions and rules under s.218A C. Land Revenue Act.
Petitioner claimed compensation for 1951-1955 ouster but gave up on understanding she would be allowed to work remaining term per Deputy Commissioner's order.
Petitioner applied twice to Divisional Forest Officer, Bhandara for permission; received letter that claim under examination; allegedly entered forests and started cutting trees.
Divisional Forest Officer (respondent No.3) on March 19, 1956 directed petitioner to stop cutting forest wood, cancelled her name, forfeited cut materials for unlawful cutting.
Petitioner applied to Government of Madhya Pradesh on September 27, 1956 to direct Divisional Forest Officer not to interfere.

Petition filed in Supreme Court under Art.32 on August 26, 1957 praying to set aside order of March 19, 1956 and direct respondents not to interfere with petitioner's rights to enter forests, appoint agents, obtain passes, manufacture charcoal etc.

legal_issues.text: Whether the order of respondent No.3 dated March 19, 1956 infringes petitioner's fundamental rights under Art.19(1)(f) and 19(1)(g).

Nature of rights granted by the unregistered document dated April 26, 1948: lease, transfer of proprietary interest, license, license coupled with grant, profit a prendre, contractual right, relating to movable or immovable property.
Whether the document requires registration under Indian Registration Act and its effect post-vesting under MP Abolition Act s.3.

petitioner_arguments.text: Offending order infringes fundamental rights under Art.19(1)(f) and 19(1)(g) derived from document dated April 26, 1948.
Rights flow from a contract; entitled to writ relying on Chhotabhai Jethabhai Patel case.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Chhotabhai Jethabhai Patel & Co. v. State of MP

petitioner_arguments.text: Deputy Commissioner validated lease despite s.6 not applying.

respondent_arguments.text: Petitioner entered forests unlawfully and started cutting trees despite pending examination.

court_reasoning.text: Whatever construction put on document (proprietary share, license, license coupled with grant as profit a prendre or contract), no infringement of fundamental rights as document unregistered, does not affect immovable property; rights vested in State under MP Act s.3; State not party to contract.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Petitioner cannot complain of breach of fundamental right; can sue grantor or State for damages if applicable.

court_reasoning.text: Document confers right to enter lands to cut certain trees and carry away wood: license coupled with grant or profit a prendre, not lease of immovable property (s.105 TPA); involves immovable property requiring registration.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Distinction between standing timber (movable) and trees (immovable); 12-year term means benefit from soil's nourishment, hence immovable.

court_reasoning.text: No fundamental right established; follows Ananda Behera over Chhotabhai as later 5-judge decision.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Purely contractual right not enforceable as fundamental right under Art.19(1)(f) or 31(1) against State not party.

court_reasoning.text: Document analysis: calls itself lease but clauses show only lease of forest woods, no proprietary rights or land enjoyment; restrictions on cutting indicate trees not mere standing timber.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Clause 5: 'Only the lease of the forest woods is given to you'; 12-year term, girth restrictions mean trees derive nourishment from soil.

holdings.text: No infringement of fundamental rights under Art.19(1)(f),(g); petition under Art.32 not maintainable.
Right to cut and remove trees over 12 years is profit a prendre involving immovable property; unregistered document ineffective.
Ananda Behera v. State of Orissa followed; Chhotabhai distinguished.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ananda Behera v. The State of Orissa
precedents_cited.relevance: Transaction is license coupled with grant/profit a prendre (immovable property); requires registration; no fundamental right.

precedents_cited.case_name: Chhotabhai Jethabhai Patel & Co. v. The State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Earlier decision on similar rights but not followed as contradicted by later Ananda Behera (5 judges vs 3); writ not available for contractual rights against non-party State.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Petition for enforcement of fundamental rights; no infringement found.

statutes_cited.name: Madhya Pradesh Abolition of Proprietary Rights (Estates, Mahals, Alienated Lands) Act, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Proprietary rights vested in State; s.6 validation not applicable to pre-1950 transfer but Deputy Commissioner allowed anyway.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Registration Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Unregistered document does not affect immovable property.

statutes_cited.name: Transfer of Property Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Not a lease; standing timber excluded from immovable property; trees otherwise immovable.

statutes_cited.name: General Clauses Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Benefit arising out of land/trees attached to earth are immovable property.

statutes_cited.name: Central Provinces Land Revenue Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Rules framed thereunder applied by Deputy Commissioner.

outcome.summary: Petition under Art.32 dismissed as no fundamental right infringed; whatever rights under document, unregistered and ineffective post-vesting; State not bound by personal/contractual rights.

key_quotes.text: whatever construction be put on this document, the petitioner cannot complain of the breach of any of her fundamental rights.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding by Das C.J. on no Art.19 violation.

key_quotes.text: the document only confers a right to enter on the lands in order to cut down certain kinds of trees and carry away the wood... a profit a prendre.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Bose J.'s characterization of the right as involving immovable property.

key_quotes.text: Standing timber are trees fit for use for building or repairing houses. This is an exception to the general rule that growing trees are immoveable property.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinction explaining why document covers immovable property.
